At altitudes above ∼50 km, radiation (mainly from the Sun) ionizes atmospheric atoms and molecules forming the ionosphere. Its refractivity is mainly controlled by the
. The propagation of the microwave signal traveling through the ionosphere results in a group delay and a phase advance.
The undesired signal in the form of wideband or narrowband interference that overlaps with the in-band frequency spectrum of
. The main sources of high-power RFI are electromagnetic signals from civilian and military ground-based communication or radar platforms. RFI detection is performed on L0B raw data before focusing.

children.value: algorithm is using an area-projection algorithm
correction factor and to geocode the data.

The motion of the Earth’s surface is driven by the gravitational pull from the Sun and the Moon (solid Earth tides), the change of the rotational axis (pole tides), the loading
effects from the ocean tides (OTL), the atmospheric and hydrological loading as well as the surface deformation. Displacements from tidal and loading effects are periodic with different time scales and amplitudes
. SET often reaches 40 and 10 cm in vertical and horizontal directions, respectively
Two components of the Total Electron Content (TEC) data from the Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) are sampled every 10 seconds along the
orbit: the integrated TEC from surface to the GNSS orbit and the top-side TEC. The difference of the two results in sub-orbital TEC is used to estimate range delay and the azimuth shifts.
At altitudes up to ~ 30 km, which forms the troposphere, refractivity is mainly controlled by temperature, water vapor, and dry air partial pressure
. The zenith hydrostatic delay is ~2.3 m at sea level at typical meteorological conditions, while the zenith wet delay varies from a few mm at the polar region to ∼40 cm at the equatorial region
. The tropospheric delay is corrected using a static tropospherical model (European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts) during focusing the raw data.
The range position of the zero-Doppler grid in maters for each point of the geographical grid of the reference/secondary RSLS
The zero-Dopple azimuth time of the zero-Doppler grid in seconds for each point of the geographical grid of the reference/secondary
The mapping of the zero-Doppler grid to the geographic grid (x component) in the units of the projection
The mapping of the zero-Doppler grid to the geographic grid (y component) in the units of the projection
The East component of the Line-Of-Sight (LOS) unit vector from the target to the sensor in the East-North-Up coordinate system for each point of the geographic grid
The North component of the Line-Of-Sight (LOS) unit vector from the target to the sensor in the East-North-Up coordinate system for each point of the geographic grid

The Up component of the Line-Of-Sight (LOS) unit vector from the target to the sensor in the East-North-Up coordinate system for each point of the geographic grid. The unit vector needs to be derived from the East and North components as:

The angle between the LOS vector and the normal to the ellipsoid at the target height
The angle between the LOS vector and the normal to the ellipsoid at the sensor
The absolute value of the platform velocity scaled at the target height
The perpendicular component of the baseline between reference and secondary
s. The baseline component is only computed for the bottom and top heights of the radar grid cubes
The parallel component of the baseline between reference and secondary
s. The baseline component is only computed for the bottom and top heights of the radar grid cubes
